multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 represent in the context of the article?
choices: A visual representation of Pascal\'s Triangle.
A generic arithmetic triangle used for illustrating the Fibonacci sequence.
A specific type of arithmetic triangle called a "binomial interpolated triangle".
A geometric proof of the binomial theorem.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Formula (1) define in the context of the article?
choices: The standard binomial transform of a given sequence.
A generalized form of the binomial transform called the "binomial interpolated transform".
The inverse of the binomial transform for a given sequence.
The relationship between the left and right diagonals of Pascal\'s Triangle.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Formula (3) express in the context of the article?
choices: The sum of elements in the k-th row of the binomial interpolated triangle.
The recursive relationship between terms in adjacent rows of the binomial interpolated triangle.
The general formula for any term (an,k) within the binomial interpolated triangle.
The inverse transformation of the binomial interpolated transform.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of Formula (2) in the article?
choices: It defines the terms of a generic arithmetic triangle.
It provides the formula for calculating any element in Pascal\'s Triangle.
It establishes the recursive relationship between elements in the binomial interpolated triangle.
It presents the formula for the binomial interpolated transform of a sequence.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of Figure 2 in relation to Figure 1?
choices: Figure 2 presents a rotated version of the triangle shown in Figure 1.
Figure 2 depicts a specific type of binomial interpolated triangle with special properties.
Figure 2 illustrates a sub-triangle within the larger binomial interpolated triangle shown in Figure 1.
Figure 2 demonstrates the relationship between binomial interpolated triangles and Pascal\'s Triangle.
